awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Sensing, Imaging and Energy Applications of Metamaterial Cloaks
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective: This project focuses on the fundamental theoretical and experimental study of metamaterial covers, operating as cloaks to suppress the otherwise inevitable disturbance that near-field sensors, imagers and absorbers produce on their surroundings. These findings will be aimed at advancing near-field measurements and imaging techniques, and increasing the efficiency of green-energy devices. Furthermore, these research concepts will be combined with a number of outreach and educational activities, aimed at integrating metamaterial research and education, with special emphasis on diversity and minorities.
Intellectual Merit: The project applies the unique property of plasmonic metamaterial shells to tunnel, capture and extract energy, combined with minimized scattering. In near-field probing applications, this may realize sensors that measure and image without perturbing their own measurement, drastically improving their overall performance. Moreover, this technology holds the potential to match, tune and maximize the efficiency of energy-harvesting devices by eliminating scattering, reflections and
unwanted coupling. Finally, this project will establish thin-film conformal metamaterial technology also suited for a variety of other applications, from radio to optical frequencies.
Broader Impacts: These results may substantially improve biomedical measurements and the efficiency of absorbing semiconductor devices. Moreover, the educational plan broadens the project?s impact through various activities, including the creation of a website, combining teaching resources on metamaterials with cutting-edge research updates, and the organization of a student symposium on metamaterials. These efforts will fill the gap between the considerable research activity on metamaterials and its currently limited educational extent, broadening the impact of these exciting topics to all society.

por.por_cntn:
The final outcomes of this research project have generally advanced the field of metamaterial cloaking. We have been able to theoretically conceive, efficiently model and design, and experimentally realize several metamaterial cloaks for a variety of applications, including: a) suppressing the otherwise inevitable disturbance that near-field sensors, imagers and absorbers produce on their own measurement and operation; b) suppressing the overall scattering from an object with improved bandwidths; c) improving the efficiency of energy-harvesting devices with metamaterial cloaks; d) improve the understanding of the exotic wave interaction with metamaterials and cloaking devices. Engaging the broad interest that these topics generate in the general public and high-school/undergraduate students, we have also been involved in several outreach programs to boost the interest of the society at large on engineering and physics studies, with special emphasis on diversity and minorities.

As major highlights of this project, we have significantly advanced the ‘plasmonic cloaking’ technique and introduced the ‘mantle cloaking’ technique for scattering suppression, making them practical for radio-frequency and THz cloaking. In the last year of the project, we have also introduced a new cloaking technique based on gradient metasurfaces. These conceptual advances have allowed us to verify cloaking experimentally for several 3-D objects, including dielectric and conducting objects, passive obstacles, transmitting and receiving antennas and sensors. We have also put forward a 3D scanning setup based on a robotic arm that enabled our lab to run extensive campaigns of far- and near-field free-space measurements, demonstrating that conformal cloaks realized by a single surface wrapped around an arbitrary object of interest can indeed produce strong scattering suppression in all directions and over a relatively broad bandwidth of operation. Another important outcome from this project has been the derivation of several fundamental bounds on cloaking in terms of bandwidth and size of the objects to be cloaked. Our results have shown what are the fundamental limits that may be achieved with any passive cloak in terms of fractional bandwidths and global bandwidths of operation, also stressing the special challenge in cloaking objects that absorb. We have also explored how these constraints may be overcome using active metamaterials, which we believe is one of the most exciting prospects opened by this project.

Our results have been published in tens of well-established and highly-selective peer-reviewed journal papers of the highest profile, covered several times throughout the duration of the project by several high-profile news outlets. The results have been presented by the involved students and the PI at tens of international conferences, invited tutorials and seminars and disseminated in various outreach efforts. Major highlights from the outreach perspective have been a TEDx talk and several disseminating videos explaining the concept of cloaking to a lay audience. These videos have received tens of thousands of views to date.

Several graduate students have been involved in this project, obtaining training in electromagnetic theory and applications, modeling, and experimental efforts in the laboratory. The graduated students have found high-profile STEM-related jobs in academia and industry.
